Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC Center for Bioenergy Research and Development - NCSU Site
Award.AbstractNarration:
Full Center Proposal (Phase I) for an I/UCRC for Bioprocessing Research and Development

0832549 South Dakota School of Mines; David Dixon
0832554 University of Hawaii; Scott Turn
0832505 South Dakota State University; William Gibbons
0832498 North Carolina State University; Steven Peretti
0832522 Kansas State University; Mary Rezac
0832520 State University of New York, Stony Brook; Devinder Mahajan

This proposal request seeks funding to establish a multi-university Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) for Bioprocessing Research and Development (CBRD). The proposed center is comprised of six universities, and is focused to make transformative discoveries to enable the lignocellulosic and fats and oil based bio-industries meet the challenges set forth by the US President, federal and state agencies and the American public. The research proposed is highly consistent with the USDA and DOE roadmaps and well integrated with the Sun Grant centers. The topic is timely and very crucial to the US, with strong academic and industry interest. The proposed research is highly interactive and multi-institutional, and has strong potential to be transformative through new discoveries. Universities participating in the proposed center have identified six initial research foci, and each of these focus areas will be addressed through numerous research projects. Additionally, the focus of the proposed center will be on activities that support and extend recent advances made by industrial partners.

CBRD is positioned to make transformative discoveries that enable the lignocellulosic and oil and fats based bio-industries to meet the challenge of declining petroleum supply. The wide range of institutions and projects proposed present numerous mechanisms for broader impact. The proposed center will serve as an educational environment, to fill the workforce pipeline with engineers and scientists needed to make use of these opportunities. This center will also provide a network of information flow to the public sector: involve K-12 outreach activities and involvement from minority participation throughout the country. It Is anticipated that the center will have direct participation from tribal colleges and historically black colleges and universities. Technology transfer is well addressed in the center plan.

ProgramReference.Text: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biorefineries convert biomass (wood, cornstalks, grasses, etc.) into energy and chemicals, and are at the heart of a robust and profitable biomass energy and products industry. Developing a bioeconomy industry requires progress in understanding not only how biomass is produced, but how it can be managed, harvested and modified to create the energy and products that consumers demand, while replacing the petroleum currently used to provide those needs. NC State University, as part of the Center for BioEnergy Research and Development, with funding from the National Science Foundation and industrial partners, has been developing the cutting edge technology required to develop a robust biorefinery. Given the long history in North Carolina of a vibrant wood pulp industry and well-managed forests, our focus has been on biorefineries utilizing wood as the primary raw material.

Cellulose and lignin are the two major components of wood. Cellulose can be converted into ethanol, while lignin has proven difficult to decompose into useful products. This is laid out in the figure, which shows generally what happens inside a biorefinery. All of the activities in red are active research areas that have been supported at NCSU by CBERD at some point. Substantial progress has been made on several topics; a few bear specific mention.

Technical and economic analysis of biorefinery structure: Several cases of developed and novel technologies applied to the treatment, decomposition and modification steps for wood, corn stover and switchgrass feeds were evaluated for technical performance and economic profitability. Important outcomes of this work include the following:

  • The concept of “value prior to combustion” was proposed and validated. Modeling around the production of ethanol and electric power as biorefinery products indicates that the yield of ethanol, and the equipment costs strongly influence the profitability of such a biorefinery.
  • While several new technologies offer the possibility of slightly increased yield for sugars or fuels, the cost of the raw material was in every case the most significant determining factor in the potential profitability of the biorefinery. The second most important was the yield of ethanol as a transportation fuel.
  • The most economically promising technology development area appeared to be the development of low-cost methods for extracting valuable compounds from the feed prior to treatment and separation of celluloses from lignin.

 

Treatment technology development: Researchers at NCSU have been instrumental in developing a technology for mechanically treating wood prior to separation into lignin and celluloses that has potential to revolutionize biorefinery design and dramatically improve profitability. Previously developed chemical treatment technologies generate inhibitory compounds that limit ethanol yield and decrease profitability. The new technology, referred to as DMR, has been evaluated using corn stover. Preliminary results indicate that the energy used for biorefining the material is significantly lower, sugar yields are equal or greater than achieved using current technology, and the enzyme costs are cut in half. All of these results suggest a dramatic increase in profitability if the technology can be scaled up appropriately.

 

Lignin deconstruction and modification: Lignin represents about 25% of wood mass, and it is currently burned as fuel. CBERD researchers at NC State have pioneered thermal and catalytic methods for the deconstruction of lignin into component molecules with potentially high value. One group used high temperatures to convert the wood into a liquid with the consistency of oil in the presence of catalysts and showed that such an approach could increase the yield of valuable aromatic compounds by approximately 25%. Another group focused on low temperatures and developed a multifunctional catalyst capable of partial lignin decomposition and preferential production of aromatic compounds, though not to the level achieved by the high temperature group. Economic analyses of the two approaches are ongoing, but both holds high potential for improved biorefinery profitability.

An international collaboration stimulated by CBERD involves the development of novel technology for the modification of lignin for the production of epoxide adhesives. The concept has been verified experimentally, and high yields (60%-80%) yields have been achieved for different types of commercially generated lignin. These adhesives are being evaluated in the production of particleboard and other laminated products by Chilean collaborators.

 In summary, CBERD has fostered and supported the development of industrial and international collaborations that have been focused on the difficult challenges facing the effort to generate fuels and products from renewable, sustainable resources instead of from petroleum. NCSU researchers have developed technologies that could provide the foundation for productive and profitable biorefineries of the future.

Modified by: Steven W Peretti
